body:
It's not specific to `select-string`

AIUI what happens is when a command has multiple parameter-sets (`Select-String` has 6) and the parameters given aren't sufficient to select one,  PowerShell will try to use the default set - which is the "File" parameter set for `Select-String`.  It will prompt for any missing parameters in that set (in this case the `file` set is missing the `pattern` parameter) and tries to continue. 

In the case of `select string`,  the default set has a `path` parameter which looks to get a `path` property from the whatever is piped and things go south from there... 

The following works  because the objects arriving at `Select-String` have a path property: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/150118924-056fc77d-238f-48a8-ad7c-f7a064a74977.png)

However; using `dir *.ps1 |  select-string` , will produce an error for each file, because File objects don't have a `path` property - they have `name`, `parent`, and `fullname` and the author of `Select-String` didn't allow for this case by giving the path parameter an alias of "FullName" 

If you **do** specify a parameter, then when something is piped in `Select-String` selects the `Object` parameter set because that will take whatever is piped in. If the object is a file, `Select-String` reads the file, if it is anything else it converts the object to a string  so    
` dir *.ps1 | Resolve-Path | select-string profile` 
will return  
`Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\FileSystem::C:\Users\ ... \profile.ps1`.
I.e. it no longer uses the path property to get the file. 

For `Select-String` the parameter sets can **probably** be altered so that 
1.  `Select-string "foo" *.ps1`   which needs the File parameter set still works but...
2.  The Object parameter set is the default.
@jhoneill  Thank you very much for a kind explaination. üëç
